item.title: Security Committee | Jurists warn of contradiction to the Basic Law
item.description: Despite support for national security issues, the requirements of the State Security Defense Commission's proposed law are considered contrary and incomprehensible in light of Macau's legal framework Analysts interviewed by Lusa consider the proposed law for the Commission for the Defense of State Security, voted yesterday in the Legislative Assembly, to be unconstitutional, highlighting “disturbing aspects”, such as restrictions on the appointment of lawyers in national security cases. The proposed law that will frame the State Security Defense Commission (CDSE) was discussed and voted on in general by deputies to the Legislative Assembly yesterday. The document, according to Macau-based lawyer Luís Almeida Pinto, “contains disturbing aspects of the constitutional functioning of various powers, and also in some matters of rights, freedoms and guarantees enshrined in the Macau ‘Constitution’: the Basic Law”. Anticipating changes to the Basic Law of the Judicial Organization, the proposal determines that the choice of a lawyer for national security cases is subject to the approval of a judge, who forwards the request to the CDSE, so that it can issue a binding and non-appealable opinion. Special authorization, the Government proposes, can occur in criminal or other proceedings, when “there are well-founded reasons to believe that there is a need to protect the interests of State security”. Almeida Pinto evokes the Basic Law, which guarantees “access to the Law, the courts, and assistance from a lawyer in the defense of their legitimate rights and interests”, to point out that it is up to the defendant “to freely choose the lawyer who best serves them”. “It seems like a rule that will be unconstitutional when approved, and when applied in practice”, he explains. Collision with Lawyer's Statute In addition to being “a violation of the Basic Law”, with constitutional force in Macau, Pedro Leal, who has practiced law in the territory for several decades, points out “clearly, a collision” between what is proposed and “the decree that regulates the Lawyers Association and the Statute” of the Lawyer, with regard to the free choice of a defender. This is the “most debatable issue” of the proposal, assumes Leal, who says he agrees with the legislative initiative. "China pays special attention to security issues, it is a world power, as such it does not want interference in any way. I understand the position and I understand that it does not want changes to the 'status quo'. (…) Now, they want to do things, do them well", he adds. Speaking to Lusa, Almeida Pinto also considers the regime envisaged to be “unacceptable” for “inquiries to be made to lawyers” who wish to legally represent a defendant in national security cases. Attached to the request made by the agents to the judge, there must be, among other elements, information regarding the members of the lawyer's household, nationality and connection with organizations or individuals abroad. This is a “real investigation into personal life”, when “what is only at stake is the exercise of the profession for which he is duly registered and authorized by the Macau Lawyers Association”, he says. The requirement, “in addition to being extremely vague, is perfectly impossible” to implement, assesses Leal, who suggests “it is implicit” that a non-Chinese lawyer will not be authorized representation in these cases – it should be noted that in cases of national security, only the intervention of Chinese judges is now permitted. Question of times Another doubt, raised to Lusa by jurist António Katchi, concerns the time it will take for the CDSE to issue the opinion. The proposal does not clarify this aspect, so the Code of Administrative Procedure “should” be applied, which sets the deadline for acts to be carried out by administrative bodies at 15 days. But, says Katchi, “will the CDSE follow this same understanding or will it consider (without the possibility of this being denied by any court) that it can simply leave the issue to its next semi-annual ordinary meeting?”. If the opinion is negative and it is necessary to repeat the process, with a new legal representative, “how many months or years will the defendant remain deprived of his liberty, without a lawyer”? Alluding to the principle of judicial independence, which he recalls is guaranteed by the Basic Law, António Katchi deduces “with complete certainty, the inadmissibility of subjecting a judicial decision to a binding opinion from an administrative body, namely the CDSE”. The professor also talks about the importance of a relationship of trust between constituent and lawyer and “how vital it is, for a person at risk of a prison sentence, to be defended by a lawyer who is sincerely motivated by the cause and well versed in the matter involved”. In addition to the Basic Law and the Joint Declaration, signed by Lisbon and Beijing in 1987, and which defined rules for Macau after the transition of administration, Katchi highlights another legal provision that the proposal contradicts: the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), according to which, he quotes, “every person accused of a crime shall have the right, in full equality, (…) to present himself at trial and to defend himself in person or to be assisted by a defender of your choice.” The ICCPR is one of the instruments that constitute the UN International Bill of Human Rights. In 1992, when Macau was still a territory administered by Portugal, Lisbon extended this convention to the region. Although China signed the treaty in 1998, it never ratified it, and is not bound by its rules. The Basic Law, explains António Katchi, points out that restrictions on fundamental rights, including the right to be assisted by a lawyer, “cannot contradict the provisions of the ICCPR”.

item.title: Cooperation | Relations between China and Timor-Leste guided by caution, study indicates
item.description: It is certain that, by being part of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, Timor-Leste can become a strategic point in commercial relations on this side of the globe, despite the “cautious pragmatism” in relations with China. The conclusion is a study on Timorese foreign policy within the scope of the Chinese initiative, authored by three Portuguese academics Timor-Leste, a young country, has been cementing its relations with China, namely through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, but there is still some caution surrounding this relationship. This is one of the conclusions of the study “Timor-Leste's foreign policy options within the scope of China's Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative: a small state perspective”, authored by academics Tiago Botelho dos Santos, Diogo Borges and Paulo Afonso Duarte. The work was published in The Pacific Review, an academic journal edited by Taylor & Francis. The research work starts with Timor-Leste's adherence to the Chinese initiative, something that happened in 2017, to analyze how the relationship with China has been going, taking into account the fact that Timor-Leste has “the status of a small state”. It is concluded, therefore, that “Timor-Leste's involvement with China's Belt and Road Initiative, particularly in the post-2023 period, can be understood as a strategic and calculated attempt to maximize its status as a small state in a complex regional and global environment”. It is described that, in this period, Timorese foreign policy has been characterized “by a multi-vector approach, strategically anchored in multilateralism”, seeking to “diversify international partnerships to reinforce national security, promote economic development and expand its voice in the international system”. The study points out that relations between Timor-Leste and China, in the context of the Belt and Road initiative, are a “deliberate movement to leverage development opportunities” in the country, being a strategy aligned with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030. The plan aims to “promote economic diversification and the development of critical infrastructure, in a context in which the Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative emphasizes digital infrastructure, green energy and cooperation in the area of ​​health”. Timorese potential The three academics also highlight that Timor-Leste, as part of the Chinese geopolitical initiative, has the potential to stand out economically, and also in commercial terms, in the region. The country has “the potential to assert itself as a logistical center on a route that connects the South Indian Ocean to the South Pacific”, so the Chinese initiative “offers a relevant opportunity to significantly increase its regional prominence and decisively facilitate” integration into ASEAN [Association of Southeast Asian Nations], to which Timor-Leste recently joined. Despite all these positive signs, the study concludes that “although Timor-Leste's relationship with China has deepened, culminating in a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2024, its engagement continues to be marked by cautious pragmatism”. In this context, “the benefits of greater connectivity and investment are carefully weighed against concerns regarding debt sustainability, transparency and possible strategic dependencies”. This caution on the part of Timor-Leste demonstrates its “capacity for action by selectively engaging in projects aligned with its national interests”, navigating the “complexities of competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, while maintaining its commitment to a balanced and diversified foreign policy”. Timorese pragmatism is also evident, according to the study, in the fact that the country “not only optimizes development opportunities, but also reinforces its regional position by meticulously analyzing economic benefits in the face of potential risks”. What is strengthened, “ultimately”, is the “capacity for action as a small State”, highlight the authors. A “remarkable” ability The study in question highlights how Timor-Leste has had “a remarkable capacity for action” in the context of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, using other small States, such as Sri Lanka, as a point of comparison. Citing other studies, the three academics highlight how “Timor-Leste has demonstrated a more cautious approach than countries like Sri Lanka, which have faced significant concerns about debt sustainability associated with BRI [Belt and Road Initiative] projects, or landlocked states like Laos and coastal nations like Cambodia.” In the case of these Southeast Asian countries, “Chinese loans for emblematic projects, such as railways and highways, have drastically increased external debt and dependence on Beijing”. What we sought to do in this investigation was “to examine the unique position of Timor-Leste, not as a financier, but also not as a victim of a ‘debt trap'”, highlighting “the distinct and valuable form of action capacity of a small State within the scope of the BRI”. The authors highlight that, in the last decade, China “significantly expanded its presence in Southeast Asia” through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, thereby “expanding its regional influence in the economic, security and political spheres”. In this relationship, Timor-Leste has been “far from being a passive observer”, seeking to “actively engage with China to ensure development benefits”. Timor-Leste sought to “identify an opportunity to align with the long-term objectives” of its Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, analysts indicate. “Strategically, the country also intends to capitalize on its geographic position in emerging commercial maritime routes, particularly through the establishment of a logistics hub in the South Indian Ocean and the South Pacific, potentially reinforcing its regional role as a new integrated member state of ASEAN”, point out the authors. Timor-Leste seeks to “balance economic gains and potential dependencies”, in a geopolitical context that “includes competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, where United States policies, under successive administrations, aim to contain China's regional influence”. In methodological terms, the authors carried out this investigation based on reading official reports, documents that serve as the basis for signed bilateral agreements and government documentation. In addition, interviews were carried out with “experts based in both Europe and Asia”. The authors state that they sought to interview academics and diplomats “due to the fact that ordinary citizens are generally unfamiliar with China's global multilateral initiatives, while diplomats tend to be excessively cautious in their statements, as they represent the official position of their state, and not necessarily their personal opinions”. It is therefore understood that academics “tend to offer more balanced and rigorous analyses”. The questions focused on how Timor-Leste, as a small State, has benefited from the Chinese initiative, whether this initiative is compatible with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, or whether “there are visible dangers of creating dependency” between the two countries, among other issues.

item.title: USJ | Book highlights panorama of philanthropy in Macau
item.description: The book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” has just been published by the University of São José. One of the chapters deals with philanthropy in Macau, the discreet profile of philanthropists and the work of entities such as Fundação Rui Cunha, Banco Nacional Ultramarino and Fundação Oriente The University of São José (USJ) has just published the book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures”, edited by professor José Manuel Simões. As the name indicates, the work aims to outline the panorama of arts, media and culture in the nine Portuguese-speaking countries and regions, which includes Macau. Macao SAR is represented with a chapter dedicated to philanthropy, written by Carmen Zita Monereo, post-doctoral student at USJ, entitled “The Impact of Corporate Philanthropy on Media, Art, and Technology in Macao / What do we know about Philanthropy in Macao? What is the relationship between Confucianism, Philanthropy, Media, and strategic communication?”. “Carmen has been developing a study on philanthropy in Macau, which is a slightly different work than the rest”, she began by telling HM José Manuel Simões. "This is a work that contributes to the analysis of the spectrum of philanthropists in Macau, then outlining a study on the Rui Cunha Foundation, Banco Nacional Ultramarino, Fundação Oriente. It looks at what corporate philanthropy is and the impacts it has on society through an analysis of the media, but also art and technology in Macau. In other words, it questions what we know about philanthropy in Macau and what is the relationship between Confucianism, philanthropy, the media and strategic communication.” José Manuel Simões adds that one of the innovative points in this chapter is the discreet profile of philanthropists. “A curious aspect is that, unlike philanthropists from Europe and the United States, who really like to appear in rankings, in Macau there is greater discretion and a low profile of these people linked to philanthropy, and this has to do with the culture itself.” The editor of the work adds that “in the field of communication sciences [in Macau] philanthropy has gained great importance as a communication instrument”, and that Carmen Zita Monereo’s work “identifies the values ​​of an organizational culture that is capable of generating communication flows conducive to innovation through this philanthropic activity”. The book, which is available for free in digital version, “seeks to draw links between various vectors, and one of them is the nine Portuguese-speaking cultures”, without forgetting Macau “as a connection platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries”. According to José Manuel Simões, it is a book “whose research was developed seeking to adopt a multidisciplinary approach”, having “an academic nature, but, at the same time, it aims to have a simple and accessible language”. Cape Verde’s good example With a bilingual edition, the book presents “a very broad spectrum” of themes, containing an article by José Manuel Simões on São Tomé and Príncipe, entitled “Digital Media Contribution to Entrepreneurship and Development in São Tomé and Príncipe”. Below is an article on the educational panorama in Angola and the use of artificial intelligence (AI), written by Wilson Gomes Caldeira, entitled “Angola’s higher education system: An analysis of the opportunities and challenges presented by Artificial Intelligence”. In the case of Cape Verde, Silvino Lopes Évora explores the ideas of social communication in conjunction with AI, in “Artificial Intelligence, newsroom culture, and journalism: From international spectrum to experiences in Cape Verde”. “Cape Verde is a good example of media development in Africa and Silvino Évora's text works on the AI ​​component in the media and how it is being inserted. [The text also analyzes] what are the possibilities for using AI and how ethics can monitor and support AI and, at the same time, journalism”, adds José Manuel Simões. The book published by USJ also explores, in the chapter “The media system as a leverage for democratic development in East Timor”, by Paulo Faustino and Rui Alexandre Novais, the links between journalism and historical memories of the independence process. The book's editor explains the “more historical component regarding the role of remission that journalists still have today to almost preserve the memory of those who died in favor of the country's independence”. "Journalism is of enormous importance in Timor, there were people and journalists who died. This is very little talked about and in this study there is an interesting conclusion, that these people, when they died in the name of freedom of expression, left a very important place in Timor-Leste that is still in force today, seeking to preserve their memory through surveillance over other powers." In this way, “Timor-Leste is almost an example of how journalism should act as a watchdog of other powers, which does not happen in other sectors”. José Manuel Simões highlights the case of Guinea-Bissau, “where journalists are called hired mouths”. "They don't know the difference between advertising, public relations, marketing and journalism, because they are conditioned by a very low salary. They write what they ask for in exchange for an envelope with some money inside, and this makes the profession [of journalism] very fragile in Guinea Bissau", he stressed. A language of unity According to José Manuel Simões, the book aims to unite “these quadrants of Portuguese cultures”, and the English edition aims to reach Anglo-Saxon communities, “so that they know about the existence of these cultures”. "There are those who do not agree with me regarding the idea that the Portuguese language is a language of unity, not only among Portuguese-speaking peoples, but even within each country. We have the case of Timor-Leste, which on the island of Ataúro alone, which is very small, with 500 thousand inhabitants, has 40 dialects, one in each village. There, what does the Portuguese language do? It unites these people, because despite there being a difference between the who speak and those who learned Portuguese, in Timor-Leste, today, the elderly speak Portuguese and young people too, but there is the age group that goes from 25 to 50, who do not speak it. But, because it is a language of learning, because it is official, because it has books, a memory, Portuguese unites all these ethnicities and dialects, and has a common value, because the Portuguese language is everyone's mother tongue”, he explains. José Manuel Simões does not forget the work that CPLP – Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, has done in this regard. "The CPLP had a wonderful idea of ​​uniting us through language, but the CPLP has done vague, limited and barely visible work. In fact, very few people have done a worthy job of creating links between new Portuguese-speaking cultures. In this sense, this book fills a gap and brings new data about these new cultures, with this technological and innovative dynamic", this in relation to the QR codes for all chapters of the book. Each code gives access to a video that summarizes the author's work in each chapter. In global terms, “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” aims to be comprehensive in areas such as technology, art, culture and social communication. There is, however, “a common denominator, creating, curiously, a certain harmony, even with different focuses, and ends up covering, directly and indirectly, the spectrum of social communication”, he concludes.

item.title: Security | Macao SAR rulers applaud White Paper on Hong Kong
item.description: China has released a new White Paper on national security, on Hong Kong, which is entitled “Practice of Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong under ‘One Country, Two Systems.’ In the Macao SAR, secretaries and political leaders reacted positively, saying that the document provides guarantees of stability and is a reference for Macau Days after the conviction in Hong Kong of Jimmy Lai, a media entrepreneur who founded the now-defunct Apple Daily newspaper, China launches a new White Paper focused on the need to safeguard national security in neighboring territory. The “Practice of Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong under ‘One Country, Two Systems'” was published by the Communication Department of China's State Council on Tuesday. According to the Xinhua news agency, this White Paper consists of five parts, detailing “the persistent struggle to safeguard national security in Hong Kong and the fundamental responsibility of the Central Government in national security matters related to Hong Kong”. In the same note, it is explained that the White Paper “exposes the achievements of the HKSAR in fulfilling its constitutional responsibility to safeguard national security” and also “Hong Kong’s transition from chaos to stability and prosperity”. “Efforts to create [a security landscape] of high standard are not forgotten in order to promote the high-quality development of the ‘One Country, Two Systems' policy”, in addition to being explained that “the Central Government applied a holistic approach to national security”. In this context, “it effectively exercised general jurisdiction over the HKSAR, in accordance with the country's Constitution and the Basic Law of the HKSAR”, and the Law on Safeguarding National Security “has been applied in the region” and has ensured “that Hong Kong is administered by patriots”. On the Macao SAR side, the government apparatus reacted positively to this White Paper, after the bill that presents a new format and composition of the Macao SAR State Security Defense Commission, created in 2018, was generally approved in the Legislative Assembly. Chan Tsz King, Secretary for Security, was one of the political figures who reacted to the document, which considers “ensuring the stable and lasting implementation” of the “One Country, Two Systems” principle. Quoted in an official note, the secretary understands that the White Paper comes to “clarify the intrinsic unity between political principles and institutional logic, causing Hong Kong society to return to normality and order to be restored”. The document, in the secretary's view, “serves as an important reference for the Macao SAR to review and improve the construction of its legal system in the context of defending the security of the State and the respective execution mechanism”. Chan Tsz King highlights that his leadership will give “great importance to ensuring security in non-traditional areas under the new situation, establishing the long-term stability of the Macao SAR as a strategic objective”. Firm as a rock Also according to Xinhua, the White Paper describes how Beijing “supports the HKSAR in fulfilling its constitutional responsibility to safeguard national security by effectively preventing, interrupting and punishing any activities that put national security at risk”. “The efforts” of the neighboring region to safeguard national security aim, according to the same document, to “sustain and develop” the principle created by Beijing to support Taiwan and the two special administrative regions, without forgetting the protection of “fundamental human rights, dignity and well-being of the 7.5 million residents of Hong Kong”. The White Paper released by the State Council also states that “in today's world, and with unprecedented global transformations that have occurred in a century, they are accelerating, with the development environment facing China undergoing profound and complex changes”. In this way, “safeguarding national security is a long-term and permanent task”, it is said. The White Paper states that Hong Kong “enjoys a high standard of security”, with the region “fated to overcome all risks and challenges in the future journey, remaining as stable as a rock in a turbulent world”. Another political figure from the Macao SAR who reacted was Adriano Marques Ho, director-general of the Customs Service, saying that the White Paper “has an important guiding significance and a profound impact for the complete and accurate implementation of ‘One Country, Two Systems’ in the Hong Kong and Macau regions, for the realization of long-term prosperity and stability, and for their stable and sustainable progression”. Adriano Marques Ho added that “both Hong Kong and Macau are inalienable and sacred parts of China”, and Beijing “has firmly and consistently maintained national sovereignty, security and development interests”. In the view of the top Customs official, “the external hostile forces and anti-China elements disturbing Hong Kong incited and created the ‘legislative review riots’, which ended up evolving into a ‘color revolution’ version of Hong Kong, seriously damaging the constitutional order and the rule of law in Hong Kong, and putting national sovereignty, security and development interests at risk”. End of the “chaotic situation” Lam, Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, said the White Paper “comprehensively analyzes and outlines Hong Kong's journey in defending national security, major achievements and experience gained”. In the government's view, “Hong Kong went from a chaotic situation to stability and prosperity”. In the case of Macau, the principles contained in the White Paper apply, with the secretary promising to “continue to intensify education, giving priority to the formation of a social base that supports the values ​​of love for the country and for Macau”. In this context, the aim is to “develop a comprehensive educational system to increase the patriotic feeling of young people and consolidate the ideological foundation of national security through multidimensional educational activities and exchanges”. It is promised that the Social Affairs and Culture department “will continue to promote national security using culture as a driving force, reinforcing the exploration and dissemination of Macau’s historical and cultural resources and organizing different types of exhibitions and cultural shows with unique characteristics”. The idea is to “spread the excellent Chinese cultural heritage in order to resist the erosion of harmful cultures, reinforce the cultural and national identity of the population and unite the forces of different sectors of society through culture”. Wong Sio Chak, Secretary for Administration and Justice, who for years held the Security portfolio, considers that the White Paper has “extreme relevance for Macao SAR issues relating to the defense of national security”, particularly with regard to “defending sovereignty, security and the development interests of the State”. The promises are that the area of ​​Administration and Justice “will boost legislative production in the priority areas related to the defense of State security, continuing to improve the respective legal regime”, with “training courses on the Constitution, the Basic Law and legislation relating to the defense of State security aimed at public service workers at different levels”. In turn, Tai Kin Ip, Secretary for Economy and Finance, described that “economic and financial security constitute non-traditional key domains among the twenty priority areas of the global vision of national security, and are also crucial factors in ensuring the stable development and long-term security of Macau and the country”. Tai Kin Ip aims to “pragmatically promote the development of adequate diversification of the economy, strengthening Macau’s global economic resilience and maintaining a high level of attention to various risks and challenges in the economic and financial domain”. Raymond Tam, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, said Macau must “cultivate an awareness of vigilance in times of peace, in order to consolidate the foundations of lasting stability and security”. In this sense, the government official understands that “Macau must always put the safeguarding of the sovereignty, security and development interests of the State first”, and in terms of Transport and Public Works he promises to “persist in the predominance of Executive power, firmly integrating the safeguarding of national security in all tasks”. Ao Ieong Seong, Commissioner against Corruption, believes that “the security and stability of the political environment and the good functioning of the system, with the predominance of the Executive branch, [guarantees that] the level of governance in the Macao SAR is increasingly higher”. The commissioner highlighted “last year’s successful holding of the elections for the 8th Legislative Assembly, reinforcing the implementation of the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots’ and effectively ensuring the lasting stability of the Macao SAR”.

item.title: Diocese of Macau/450 years | New Catholic Center will have a hotel
item.description: The new Catholic Center should open “in the middle of the second quarter” of this year and will have a hotel, prepared to receive “pilgrims and tourists”, says the Diocese of Macau. At a time when the institution celebrates 450 years, the inauguration of the Catholic Center is based on “the vision” of D. Paulo José Tavares, bishop of Macau in the 60s and 70s After many years of emptiness and construction work on the corner of Avenida da Praia Grande and Rua do Campo, the new Catholic Center is preparing to open its doors later this year and is perhaps the most important event in the celebration of the 450th anniversary of the Diocese of Macau. HM asked questions to the Diocese of Macau regarding the reopening of the building, which confirmed that the official inauguration is scheduled “for the second quarter” of this year. This building, with a total of 17 floors, will have features designed for religious purposes, but also a hotel prepared to receive all types of people. "The Catholic Center will be a nerve center for disseminating and sharing the mission of the Catholic Church. The lower floors will feature a chapel, an auditorium, conference rooms, exhibition areas and spaces for activities." While “the upper floors will function as a hotel, offering welcoming and comfortable accommodation, imbued with a spirit of service”. In the diocese's written response, it is added that the hotel facilities “were designed to receive both pilgrims and tourists, welcoming Catholics and non-Catholics with hospitality and inclusion”. It is worth remembering that in December employees began to be recruited for the hotel unit, in partnership with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL). In a job matching session aimed at residents, held on December 5th, with the “Companhia de Gestão do Centro Católico”, 23 job openings were made available for sales manager, assistant reception manager, chef, head of security, room service supervisor and acquisition supervisor, reads the DSAL note released in November. The Diocese of Macau did not want to tell HM how much it would cost to rebuild the new Catholic Center, saying only that initial forecasts had slipped due to the pandemic. "The Catholic Center is currently undergoing development and submission and approval by the Government. Following the challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic, construction costs have increased significantly. We are grateful for the understanding and support of the builders and contractors, which allowed the reconstruction project to be completed successfully. At the same time, we warmly welcome donations from all sectors of society to help sustain and carry forward the Catholic Center's original mission of serving the Macau community." A bishop still present Asked about the main goals of the new Catholic Center, the Diocese of Macau describes that the building “aims to continue the spiritual mission of the Catholic Church and incorporate the spirit of Christ”, influenced by the work of Bishop D. Paulo José Tavares, who carried out his mission in Macau in the mid-20th century. Of particular note is the fact that D. Paulo José Tavares, who died in 1973 and was appointed Bishop of Macau in 1961, was important in maintaining the presence of the Catholic Church in Macau at the time of the “1,2,3” movement. Between November 1966 and February 1967, the Cultural Revolution manifested itself in the territory, bringing together many local students, who intended to change the content of Catholic education. D. Paulo José Tavares fought with these groups of protesters, managing to keep teaching in Catholic schools and the spirit associated with them unchanged. In this way, and based on “the vision” of this bishop, the diocese intends for the new Catholic Center to “continue to serve as a vital bridge for the Macau community, promoting dialogue, exchange and integration of faith and culture”. It is also the intention to “open the doors [of the Center] to visitors from all over the world, reinforcing not only its role as a spiritual refuge, but also infusing new vitality into the religious and cultural panorama of Macau”. António Pedro Costa, author of the cleric's biography, entitled “D. Paulo José Tavares – The diplomat bishop”, described, in an interview with HM in 2023, that the bishop “was a breath of fresh air”, and a figure cherished by the Chinese community at the time. "These attitudes of valuing the Chinese community led to a rapprochement and the establishment of a relationship of trust. Only in this way was he able to take his objectives forward, as he realized that he had to have the population on his side. But this caused him a lot of trouble with the European clergy, who did not agree with D. Paulo José Tavares' stance. It meant that the population saw him as an ally and not a person who comes from outside and imposes his ideas", said the author. A year of celebrations It was in 1576, in the fourth year of the Wanli reign, of the Ming Dynasty, that the Diocese was founded in Macau, with January 23rd being the official date of celebration. However, the next few months will also be festive. In a previously released statement, the Diocese of Macau states that it has had, over the years, “the mission of establishing bridges between East and West, promoting education, charity and pastoral service”, leaving “a deep and lasting mark on the cultural, educational and religious development of Macau”. The theme of the celebrations is “From Macau to the World: 450 years of Mission and Mercy”. The new Catholic Center will host two thematic exhibitions, entitled “Honoring the Past, Creating the Future” and “Witness to Heritage, Mission in the World”. These exhibitions aim to “reflect the development of the Diocese from historical, personal and cultural perspectives, as well as its future directions”, highlights the same note. Tomorrow a sacred music concert will take place at the Sé Church with eight choral groups from Macau, Hong Kong and the Province of Guangzhou, with the sounds of the church's new pipe organ being heard. From 7:30 pm onwards, the Diocesan Choir of Macau, the Cathedral Schola ensemble and other choral groups from Macau will perform, such as Coro Perosi, Dolce Voce and Cantate Chorus, without forgetting other ensembles from Hong Kong and Guangzhou. The Diocese highlights that the “most symbolic and large-scale initiative of the commemorative year” will be the “great celebration” scheduled for October 31st this year, which consists of a reception and mass. “Through this solemn celebration, the Diocese will give thanks to God for the graces and mission granted over four and a half centuries, and will pray that He continues to guide the way forward”, the same statement describes. There will also be initiatives carried out by “various diocesan institutions” in the coming months, namely “cultural shows, school competitions, academic symposiums, social activities, youth meetings, online training resources, parish initiatives and liturgical celebrations”. “Through transversal and intergenerational participation, the commemorative year seeks to deepen public knowledge about the historical development of the Diocese and its service to the community, promoting the spirit of the diocesan motto ‘Scientia et Virtus’ (Science and Virtue), which inspires a practice of service based on the balance between knowledge and ethical care.” At a time when it celebrates 450 years of existence, the Diocese says it wants to chart the future, “walking with the residents of Macau in reflecting on the past and continuing its mission of faith, service and culture in this new stage”.

item.title: History | Book reveals how Macau was created in the image of Évora
item.description:
The local association Heritage Society has just released a two-volume book on the history of Macau's founding. Authored by Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos, “Foral of the City of the Name of the God, Macau”, contains translations and annotations of documents that show how the founding of Macau had Évora as a model
A book, divided into two volumes, has just been published by the local association Heritage Society, which helps tell the story of the founding of Macau, from the mid-16th century onwards. The two volumes are entitled “Foral of the City of the Name of the God, Macau: Évora of the Far East” and “The Twenty-eight Alvarás”, and are authored by academics Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos. The first volume, which establishes a curious connection between Macau and Évora in the founding of the territory to the East, is based on the archive “Foral, Regalias e Privilégios Concedidos à Cidade de Macau, na China, 1596-1756”, the original of which is kept at the National Archives of Rio de Janeiro, and there are microfilms at the Macau Archive. In turn, the part dedicated to the 28 charters, a continuation of the first volume, analyzes the 28 legal texts initially decreed by the then governor of Macau and viceroy of India, D. Rodrigo da Costa, in 1689. These documents were later confirmed by King D. João V, in Portugal, in 1709. As the authors told HM, in a joint email interview, the first volume “deals with the first part of the archive, or the first 17 sheets, which concern the oldest founding letters, letters and sentences received by the Senate of Macau during the last years of the 16th century”. The second volume analyzes the contents of the file between pages 17 and 33, covering the 28 permits. “This is not yet the complete story, as we intend to continue working on the remaining archive in future years”, confessed the authors. The authors highlight the importance of the charter, an ancient document that consisted of “a charter or contract that the governing power, be it a feudal lord, a bishop or a king, establishes with a local entity, be it a village or city, a senate or a council”. "We consider that the word and the concept are important to reflect on this historical period and not only in Macau, but also the time when the European kingdom [Portugal] was at the height of its expansion across the seas and oceans. The concept of charter implies the way in which a Portuguese social structure was being transplanted and rethought in Macau." In this way, the authors add, all documents analyzed for these two volumes are related to the idea of ​​charter. In turn, the designation “City of the Name of God of Macau” appears, in this specific file, “not only in the charter of King Philip I of Portugal, during the Iberian Union, which stipulates the elevation of Macau from a town to a city, but also throughout the 28 subsequent charters”. In concrete terms, readers can come across “a research work that addresses some of the most important documents in the history of Macau, documents that inform us about the founding of the city and the evolution of its legal and governing tradition”. The connection with Évora The first volume of the work includes the subtitle “Évora of the Far East”, relating “the story in which the town's Senate presented a petition to the Viceroy of India for the recognition of the Senate, for the elevation of this port to the status of city and for the granting to the 'new city' of Macau of the privileges, rights and freedoms of the city of Évora”. D. Duarte de Meneses, at the time governor of Macau and viceroy of India, ended up granting this request on behalf of King D. Filipe I, in 1586, a “decision that was later confirmed by the king himself in 1595”. “To confirm and corroborate that Macau had the same status as Évora, it became natural that all the founding documents of the city of Évora were transcribed to Macau, so that the Senate of Macau could preserve them as evidence and keep them in its archives as founding documents of the city”, explain the authors. The documents found in the archive based in Rio de Janeiro point out that “the ‘proof’ of Macau’s status as a city comparable to Évora does not consist of a single document, but a compilation of several texts”. In the first volume of the work there are examples such as “sentences on the jurisdiction of certain positions, such as the Prosecutor and the Almotacé, royal letters on specific issues, laws on which positions should be part of a Senate, rites of religious and funeral processions and even the configuration of the Senate room”. In short, “everything that Évora possessed de jure during this period was inherited by Macau, as proven by the meticulous transcription and authentication of these documents”, explain the authors. The survival permits Regarding the second volume of the work, focused on the 28 permits, the authors understand that these documents “are particularly significant because they present themselves as a cohesive set, with great integrity in terms of language, format, administration and argumentation”. For Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos, this results from the fact that, at the end of the 17th century, Macau was no longer in its golden period of trade, “due to the loss of commercial routes”. "At the same time, Macau faced constant social unrest, both internally – for example, between the Senate, the Captain-General and the Ouvidor – and externally, in relations with the Chinese and Castilians. The privileges and rights of the Senate were not respected, and it was necessary to resolve ambiguities to guarantee the city's survival, as reflected in the various minutes of the Senate meetings." Thus, a petition was presented by these bodies to governor D. Rodrigo da Costa “for the reaffirmation of the city's rights and to present solutions to various problems, such as the overflow of the jurisdiction of the Captain-General, the preservation of the Padroado in the face of foreign missionary groups and trade with the Chinese and in Solor and Timor”. Thus, the 28 permits emerged, which “also deal with a very diverse group of people from different arts, professions, origins and ideologies”, and not just relations between Portuguese and Chinese, which made “this set of documents particularly interesting to study”. The aim of publishing these two volumes was to facilitate access to the archive and its information. “We intend to place in the hands of Macau readers a fundamental document of the legal and political origin of the city, which remains little studied, even in Portuguese-speaking historiography, and which is almost completely absent from the daily historical imagination of Macau”, they add. The archive based in Rio de Janeiro was translated by the authors “and was never published in full, especially the founding documents related to Évora, not even in Portuguese”. This archive almost always appears “indirectly, as excerpts and paraphrases, such as those of canonical historians of Macau, in the case of Manuel Teixeira; or as references inserted in specialized works, and in some cases only through digitalized transcriptions that circulate in doctoral theses”. In the case of permits, they are “better known among historians, but appear only in very limited publications”. "For this reason, the publication of the primary text itself becomes essential. By presenting it in English and Chinese, alongside Portuguese, we also seek to remove a barrier that has long structured Macau's historiography, dividing the city's documentary past into separate linguistic archives that rarely dialogue with each other", they conclude. Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos also understand that “these volumes offer new answers in historiographical terms, because they show with renewed clarity that the legal existence of Macau emerged through the transplantation and local adaptation of the Portuguese municipality [Évora] as a governing idea on an Asian border”. “At its core, the archive poses a fundamental question that often remains implicit: what counted as ‘Portuguese territory’ in its smallest civic unit, and how could this unit be reconstructed overseas through privileges, positions and jurisdiction, after Portugal had become global from the 15th century onwards?” Local management Regarding the relationship between Portugal and China at the time, the authors state that the work shows how “relations between China and Portugal in Macau were not carried out mainly through formal diplomacy between two distant courts, but through the daily management of coexistence by local institutions, in conditions of unequal jurisdiction”. The first volume of the book shows how “the king elevated Macau from a town to a city and confirmed the elections of councillors, judges and officials because the Captain-Major appointed to China frequently left for the annual trip to Japan, remaining only a short time there and leaving the settlement without continuous leadership”. The original document reveals that “this situation was especially dangerous in China, given Macau's distance from India and the fact that supplies could only be made during the annual trip”. In this way, “municipal government is presented as a necessity: a frontier city could not wait for an absent commander nor could it allow disorder.” Thus, the authors add, “the privileges, jurisdiction and civic positions granted to Macau describe a political logic as much as a legal one, since the Portuguese presence depended on a permanent local body capable of maintaining peace and managing risks in a space where the superior authority was distant”. Regarding the permits, they show what maintaining the stability of the territory entailed, as “the survival of Macau depended on remaining within the limits tolerated by the Chinese authority”. "The Twenty-sixth Alvará, for example, is explicit in stating that the Chinese mandarinate did not accept Portuguese jurisdiction over Chinese subjects, especially when Christian creditors sought to arrest Chinese debtors. The Senate describes the expenses and dangers caused when a mandarin was sent to enforce such determinations and requests a direct solution: preventing Christians from contracting credits with the Chinese and denying them recourse to both the Ombudsman and the Chinese courts, so that the city could 'live in peace’. The Crown confirms this approach”, they conclude.

item.title: Elections | Portugal prepares to choose the next President of the Republic
item.description:
Portugal goes to the vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Republic. Of the 11 candidates, only two have representatives from Macau: Bessa Almeida from the PSD, and Neto Valente from the PS. The former president of the Macau Lawyers Association highlights that António José Seguro “does not join in provocations against China”, while Bessa Almeida considers that Marques Mendes is the right man for the moment
Eleven candidates will vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Portuguese Republic, for a five-year term. This is a record number, with only seven having the support of political parties. Running for the position is Luís Marques Mendes, supported by the Social Democratic Party (PSD), and who appointed António Bessa Almeida as his representative in the Macao SAR. Next comes António José Seguro, with the support of the Socialist Party (PS), which has Jorge Neto Valente, president of the Macau Portuguese School Foundation and lawyer, as his representative. They are the only candidates for the Presidency of the Republic who chose figures as representatives of the Macao SAR. The remaining candidates are Henrique Gouveia e Melo, João Cotrim de Figueiredo, Catarina Martins, António Filipe, André Ventura Jorge Pinto, Manuel João Vieira, André Pestana and Humberto Correia. To HM, António Bessa Almeida, PSD activist and explained the reasons for supporting Marques Mendes. “At the time Portugal is going through, the country needs a candidate like Marques Mendes, who has a deep understanding of the different policies”, he began by pointing out. Asked about the type of actions developed in Macau to attract the electorate to vote for Marques Mendes, Bessa Almeida simply mentioned that “the campaign in Macau is totally different from that in Portugal”, and the actions developed involve “what the candidate does in close proximity to the people, passing on information”. For Bessa Almeida, “the electorate in Macau, on the Chinese side, is also made up of Portuguese”, and that “they have been following these elections like any other Portuguese, with confident visions for the future of Portugal”. On January 6th, the president released a note highlighting the importance of Marques Mendes' candidacy, who is currently far from the top spots in the polls. "We have always been concerned with everything related to Portugal and at this moment, at a global level, political changes are sudden and unexpected. That is why we need a visionary president, experienced and thoughtful in guiding the destinies of Portugal and Portuguese people born and living outside the country."
A safe return In Portugal, polls relating to the presidential elections have taken place almost daily, and show a change in the choice of candidates. If initially António José Seguro was somewhat removed from the top positions, a survey carried out by the Universidade Católica Portuguesa for RTP, Antena 1 and the Público newspaper, between the 6th and 9th of January and released this week, shows how Seguro is in a technical tie with André Ventura, Chega's candidate, guaranteeing 23 percent of voting intentions, when Ventura collects 24 percent. João Cotrim de Figueiredo comes in third place, with 19 percent, with the possibility of going to the second round of elections, followed by Marques Mendes and Gouveia e Melo with 14 percent. Another survey, this time for TVI, CNN, TSF and Jornal de Notícias, with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January, shows Seguro with 23.9 percent of voting intentions, followed by Cotrim de Figueiredo with 20.8 percent and Ventura with 20.5 percent. Marques Mendes falls to fifth place, with 13.2 percent. Seguro chose, in the Macao SAR, Jorge Neto Valente as his agent, who did not answer HM's call. In a statement published in the newspapers this Wednesday, the former president of the Macau Lawyers Association declared that Seguro “proposes a vision of the future based on the modernization of the country, the valorization of education and a focus on innovation”. Referring specifically to Portugal-China relations, Neto Valente highlights that “unlike other candidates, Seguro does not support China's provocations regarding the status of Taiwan, and is also a candidate who “knows Portugal, Europe and the world”. Neto Valente also stated that Seguro “is a decent man”. “He participated in all debates, showed politeness, defended his ideas firmly, was never excessive in his language and, unlike others, did not insult opponents or make malicious insinuations toward them.”
A “consistent course” Paulo Pisco, leader of the Insurance campaign for emigration, reminded HM that the candidate “even expressed the opinion that, given that it was an in-person vote [for the presidential elections], the Government could have done much more, namely complying with what the electoral law for the Presidency of the Republic says, which is the possibility of opening more polling stations”. Seguro also defended, according to Paulo Pisco, “that mobility voting could also have been applied, based on the experience previously carried out in the last elections for the European Parliament”. Paulo Pisco states that António José Seguro has followed a “very consistent, solid and objective path”, which has allowed him to reach the top of the polls. Regarding the emigrated electorate, the deputy highlights that Seguro “has not deviated from the purposes, form and values ​​with which he intends to exercise the Presidency of the Republic”. Furthermore, it is “a guarantor of the stability of the political system and also of democracy”. “This image that the candidate António José Seguro has shown throughout his career has earned him greater receptivity from voters”, highlighted Paulo Pisco. The president does not forget that “Seguro is the candidate who has the most representatives per country in our diaspora”. "There are 18, ten in Europe and eight outside Europe. I believe that this substantiates a very firm commitment from the candidate to the exercise of his functions as President of the Republic, and to the relationship he intends to have with the diaspora", he stressed. Looking at the candidates lower down in the polls, we have many faces from the left. The same survey with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January places Catarina Martins, from Bloco de Esquerda, with 2.5 percent; followed by António Filipe, from PCP, with 1.4 percent, head to head with Jorge Pinto, from Livre, who has 1.3 percent. Manuel João Vieira, visual artist and musician, obtains 1 percent of voting intentions.

item.title: HZM Border | Concession yields 1.2 million per month
item.description: Sociedade Express Grupo Limitada will pay 1.2 million patacas monthly to the Macao SAR to operate the commercial areas of the Macau Border Post Building on the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge (HZM). The information was published yesterday in the official bulletin, where the contract was announced. The contract has a duration of five years, meaning the final amount paid to the Macao SAR should be around 72 million patacas. The deadline starts from the effective start of exploration, which can happen until May 31st. As part of the contract, the concessionaire commits to ensuring that 30 percent of the commercial space comes into operation, excluding self-service services. Furthermore, the company can change the space to expand commercial areas, but is obliged to maintain good business and hygiene conditions. If the commercial area is increased, the contract also provides for an increase in the monthly rent price, calculated according to the effective increase in space. Sociedade Express Grupo was founded in 1999 in Macau and its main activity is operating pharmacies, linked to the Wan Tung brand, with around 30 spaces in the territory. However, its activities also extend to travel agency services, and the company's portal guarantees that it is the main representative in Macau of Cebu Airlines, although it also has links with other companies such as China Eastern, China Southern, Eva Air, among others.

item.title: Casinos | Taxes charged increase 15% in January
item.description: The gaming sector represented 85.6 percent of taxes collected in January, with a total of MOP8.2 billion. Tax revenues from the territory's main industry increased by 14.6 percent compared to January 2025, when they did not reach 7.2 billion patacas Last January, the Government recorded 9.62 billion patacas in current revenue, 14.5 percent more than in January 2025. Of total current revenue, the portion corresponding to taxes on gaming concessionaires was more than 8.2 billion patacas, which represents 85.6 percent of all current revenue, according to data published on the Finance Services Directorate's website. In comparative terms, tax revenue generated by casinos in January increased by 14.6 percent, compared to the same month in 2025, when they reached almost 7.2 billion patacas, a difference of more than 1,000 million patacas. It is recalled that according to the new gaming concessions, which came into force for a decade on January 1, 2023, the tax on casinos' gross revenues was set at 40 percent. When counting capital revenues (sale of facilities and equipment, financial assets, sale of shares and other holdings), total revenues from public coffers in January recorded almost 9.64 billion patacas. The other side Representing almost all public revenue, revenue from the gaming sector is crucial to the Macao SAR Budget. For now, the Government estimates that 2026 will end with gross revenues from the territory's casinos of around 236 billion patacas, which will give around 19.7 billion patacas per month. To achieve this goal, January has already exceeded the estimated monthly average of around 2.93 billion patacas, when the sector's gross revenues registered more than 22.63 billion patacas, 24 percent more compared to January 2025. If a positive performance during the Chinese New Year holidays is confirmed, casino gross revenues could record an annual increase of around 18 percent in the first quarter of the year. In terms of expenses, January data from the DSF reveals that personnel expenses were around 1.19 billion patacas, 0.17 percent less compared to January 2025. In relation to public expenses to pay transfers, support and allowances, around 2.8 billion patacas came out of public coffers in January, 0.35 percent more in annual terms. Overall, January ended with revenues almost doubling expenses, with the balance for last month's financial year in positive territory at almost 5 billion patacas.

item.title: Urbanism | City beautification follows Xi's spirit
item.description: The Secretary for Administration and Justice, Wong Sio Chak, led the first meeting of the year of the City Beautification and Cleaning Working Group and highlighted that the tasks to be performed serve to “implement the spirit of President Xi Jinping's important speeches” during his visit to Macau, in December and 2024. Based on these statements, Wong Sio Chak demanded that the group do “increasingly professional work”, while “strengthening cooperation, implementing an accountability system, safeguarding security, listening to the population's opinions and improving the quality of life of residents”. Regarding the main tasks for this year, Wong defined five requirements: first, refine responsibilities and ensure implementation [of work]; second, strictly control quality and ensure safety; third, work diligently and pragmatically to create a new landscape; fourth, strengthen coordination and cooperation; and fifth, increase public awareness and promote collaboration between the Government and the population. Wong Sio Chak also hoped that the entire working group would be guided by the spirit of President Xi Jinping's important speech in order to jointly contribute to the beautification of the city.

item.title: One Country, Two Systems | Sam wants Macanese to tell history “well”
item.description: The Government leader indicates that the community has a role to play in the integration of Macau into Mainland China and highlighted the value of the community in connecting China and abroad The Chief Executive wants the Macanese community to work with the Government to “guarantee the good safeguard and development” of Macau and “tell well” the story of “the successful implementation of ‘One Country, Two Systems’ in China and abroad”. Sam Hou Fai's tasks for the Macanese were left during a dinner, which took place on Tuesday, with some members of the community. According to the Government's report, at the meeting Sam Fou Fai “guaranteed that he was available to work together with the Macanese community in order to guarantee the good safeguard and development of this home [Macau]”. However, the tasks don't stop there. The leader of the Executive also wants Macanese to move “proactively in the Cooperation Zone in Hengqin and the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area” and to “actively” participate in the construction of these projects. Sam Hou Fai also highlighted that the Macanese have a place in the integration of Macau within Mainland China and that the community “fully plays out its unique advantages in language, culture, gastronomy, professionalism and interconnection with the world, helping the Macao SAR to create a relevant connection ‘door’ for the country in high-quality openness to the outside world and a privileged ‘window’ for exchange and mutual learning between Chinese and Western civilizations”. Importance assured In the message left during dinner, Sam Hou Fai also pointed out that the Government will “give importance and support the Macanese community, hoping that it can enhance its uniqueness, actively participate in the integration between Macau and Hengqin and in the construction of the Greater Bay Area”. Sam Hou Fai highlighted that the “economic and social development of the Macao SAR has been stable and progressive, basically achieving the main objectives and tasks of governance, whose government action work in the first year of the Government proceeded smoothly and stably, with reforms, innovations, advances and results”. Sam also promised to execute the Government Action Lines and stated that he believes that within the scope of the planned tasks there will be “ample opportunities” for the Macanese community “to contribute significantly and achieve notable achievements”.

item.title: Bookstores | Deputy wants more support
item.description: Representative Lam Fat Iam defended yesterday that more support should be created for the book sector, supporting “the development of local physical bookstores” and the construction of Macau as a “City of Reading”. Speaking during the period of interpellations before the agenda, Lam Fat Iam argued that “specific and precise support policies” must be created, such as the creation of “support programs for the exploration and cultural activities of bookstores”, giving “priority to bookstores that promote Macau culture and regularly hold conferences and reading activities”. A system must also be created that encourages “the circulation and publication of local books”, with “priority financing for the planning, editing and publication of books with Macau characteristics”.

item.title: Terraces | “Systematic planning” request
item.description: Deputy Chui Sai Peng argues that the authorities should carry out “systematic planning” of the terraces, in order to “create a pleasant and relaxed atmosphere” taking into account Macau’s role as a city of gastronomy. During the period of interpellations before the agenda, Chui Sai Peng said that it is not enough for the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM) to have resumed issuing licenses, there must be “a detailed and long-term plan”, defining “general objectives for planning Macau's outdoor dining spaces, the path to practice, the size of the projects and short-term action plans”. The deputy therefore requests that “a working group be created, in order to draw up a plan for the terraces, scientific, executable and consensual, between multiple parties”.

item.title: Flights | Direct connections between Macau and PLP defended
item.description: Representative Song Pek Kei yesterday defended the creation of direct air links between the territory and Portuguese-speaking countries, with the aim of “enriching the air network” of the territory. “It is important to launch incentive measures to encourage operators in the [airline] sector to explore more direct international routes, with priority being given to expanding the direct flight network with Portuguese and Spanish-speaking countries,” said Song Pek Kei, in an intervention at the Legislative Assembly (AL). The Macau Civil Aviation Activity Law came into force this year, opening the door to the liberalization of the sector. Song Pek Kei stated that, with the entry into force of this legislation, the Government “must accelerate” the adjustment of the service structure and “make good use” of resources to develop more routes with stopovers and connections. “Taking the experiences of other regions as a reference, it is important to launch incentive measures to encourage operators in the sector to explore more direct international routes,” he added. Other requests Song Pek Kei is not the first deputy to propose to the Government the creation of new air routes that connect the Chinese region to Europe. In December, Ip Sio Kai also defended the establishment of a direct air link with Lisbon, to promote business between Portuguese-speaking countries and Europe. Ip suggested that the Government grant subsidies for the opening of this long-haul flight and launch promotions for accommodation, transport and cultural activities to attract tourists to Macau. In response to Ip Sio Kai in the hemicycle, the president of the Civil Aviation Authority, Pun Wa Kin, stated that the Government “attaches great importance” to the development of aviation, “in particular its role in promoting economic diversification”. “However, in commercial operations, airlines often consider market demand, operational costs, long-term benefits and the competitiveness of the route, before deciding to launch new flights”, declared Pun Wa Kin, to whom the Government Head of Transport and Public Works, Tam Vai Man, had handed over the prerogative of responding to the deputy. When Ip suggested that the Government could subsidize the route, Pun responded that this support “involves different sectoral policies” and that “the Macao SAR Government needs to analyze the issue comprehensively, from all aspects”.

item.title: The Dispute over Greenland (II)
item.description: “Nations do not compete for land; they compete for the power that land unlocks.” Halford J. Mackinder The position of the European Union (EU) in the face of the United States' growing attention to Greenland, intensified during Donald Trump's presidency, generated concern and strategic reflection. Although Greenland has not been part of the EU since 1985, the island remains part of the Kingdom of Denmark, a Member State of the Union, which gives the issue an unavoidable political and institutional dimension. The European position thus results from the need to protect the territorial integrity of one of its members, to safeguard strategic interests in the Arctic and to preserve the stability of transatlantic relations. The EU views Greenland as part of the broader European political space, not because of its formal membership, but because of its constitutional connection to Denmark. Any external attempt to acquire or exercise control over territory is interpreted as a direct interference with the sovereignty of a Member State. The American proposal to purchase the island was received in Brussels as a disruptive diplomatic gesture, which went beyond the traditional limits of cooperation between allies. The defense of Danish sovereignty constitutes the first pillar of the European position. The EU has reiterated that the territorial integrity of its Member States is non-negotiable and that any change to the status of a European territory requires full and voluntary consent from national and local authorities. The idea of ​​a territorial transaction, reminiscent of 19th century practices, contradicts contemporary principles of international law and European governance. The EU recognizes the Arctic as a region of growing importance, both for its environmental relevance and its geopolitical value. The accelerated melting of ice, the opening of new maritime routes and access to strategic mineral resources transformed the region into a space for competition between great powers. The EU, which defines itself as a “global actor”, seeks to ensure that the Arctic remains a zone of peaceful cooperation, governed by multilateral norms and shared management mechanisms. American interest in Greenland is interpreted in Brussels as part of a broader strategy of military and economic assertion in the Arctic. Although the United States is a fundamental ally within NATO, the EU maintains reservations about unilateral initiatives that could alter the regional balance. The excessive militarization of Greenland, particularly through the possible installation of nuclear weapons, would be seen as a factor of instability, with a direct impact on European security. Greenland has vast reserves of critical minerals, including rare earths, essential for the energy transition and the European technology industry. The EU has sought to reduce dependence on external suppliers, especially China, and sees cooperation with Greenland as an opportunity to strengthen its strategic autonomy. The American interest in controlling these resources raises concerns in Brussels, which fears an excessive concentration of power over vital supply chains. The EU argues that mining exploration in Greenland must be carried out in a sustainable, transparent manner and in partnership with European actors, guaranteeing benefits for the local population and avoiding predatory exploration practices. The EU deeply values ​​the transatlantic relationship, but considers that strong alliances require mutual respect and predictability. The American proposal to acquire Greenland was interpreted as a gesture that disregarded European political sensitivity and put trust between partners at risk. Brussels sought, however, to avoid a diplomatic escalation. The European response combined firmness in defending Danish sovereignty with discursive moderation, in order to preserve strategic cooperation with Washington in areas such as defense, trade and international security. The EU stressed that dialogue on the Arctic should take place in multilateral forums and within the framework of NATO, and not through unilateral initiatives. Trump's statements at the 2026 Davos Forum further intensified these tensions. Before global leaders, Trump stated that the United States “will not use force” to acquire Greenland, although he stressed that the country would be “frankly unstoppable” if it decided to do so. He added that “no other nation can defend Greenland” and that Washington intended to begin “immediate negotiations” to take control of the territory. In one of the most controversial passages, he declared: "We want a piece of ice to protect the world, and they won't give it. You can say yes and we will be very grateful, or you can say no and we will remember." Trump also reinforced the historical narrative according to which the United States “saved Greenland” during World War II and insinuated that returning the territory to Denmark would have been a mistake. He repeated criticism of NATO, accusing European allies of contributing little to common security, and threatened to impose tariffs of 10% on several European countries, increasing to 25% if the sale of Greenland did not go ahead. European reactions were immediate and firm. Danish Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen considered it “positive” that Trump had taken the military option off the table, but stressed that “the president’s ambition remains intact” and that American pressure continued to be unacceptable. In Brussels, the statements were interpreted as a rhetorical escalation that undermined trust between allies and sought to transform Greenland into an instrument of economic and strategic blackmail. European diplomats called the speech “bellicose” and “out of line with the spirit of cooperation” expected at the Davos Forum, noting that the threat of tariffs on EU Member States constituted a form of coercion incompatible with stable transatlantic relations. Denmark, although responsible for Greenland's foreign and defense policy, faces specific challenges in managing the territory. The island's growing autonomy, combined with interest from external powers, places Copenhagen in a delicate position. The EU has sought to support Denmark, strengthening its negotiating capacity and offering instruments for economic and scientific cooperation with Greenland. Brussels understands that the region's stability depends on a balanced relationship between Denmark's interests, the aspirations of the Greenlandic population and the need to avoid external interference that could compromise European security. Therefore, the EU's position regarding the American interest in Greenland is based on three fundamental principles; the uncompromising defense of the sovereignty of a Member State; the preservation of stability and cooperation in the Arctic; and the protection of European strategic interests in critical resources and regional security. Trump's statements in Davos reinforced the European perception that the issue goes beyond a mere territorial dispute, revealing an assertive American strategy that combines economic pressure, historical narrative and geopolitical ambition. Although it recognizes the importance of the transatlantic partnership, the EU rejects unilateral approaches that could weaken the European political balance or transform the Arctic into a stage for confrontation between great powers. Greenland, located between continents and between logics of power, has become a test of the EU's ability to assert its strategic autonomy and protect its members in an increasingly competitive international context.
