item.title: Seat belts (I)
item.description: Hong Kong implemented the “Road Traffic (Safety Equipment Regulation 2025) Amendment” on January 25, which requires all bus passengers to wear seat belts. Violators can face fines of up to HK$55,000 and be sentenced to imprisonment for up to three months. On January 30, just six days after the law came into force, the Hong Kong Government announced its suspension. The amendment will be rewritten before being submitted to the Legislative Council for review. Why was the law suddenly suspended six days after it came into force? The suspension was due to the occurrence of three incidents that gave rise to some reflection on the matter. The first involved a passenger who was unable to unfasten his seat belt and was trapped for around 16 minutes. Twenty firefighters from the Fire Department were sent to help. After carrying out an inspection, Citybus Co. Ltd. discovered that aluminum foil had been placed inside the belt buckle, a suspected act of vandalism, and reported the incident to the police. This case demonstrated the potential risk of mandatory seat belt use during emergency evacuations and raised questions about whether passengers could cut their seat belts to escape in dangerous situations. When reviewing or analyzing a law, it is crucial that there is “clear discernment and careful consideration.” If a passenger needs to escape following an accident and is unable to unfasten their seat belt, do they have the right to cut it to escape? In other words, could the law give people the right to damage other people's property in order to escape? Under Hong Kong law, damaging other people's property is a criminal offence. To convict a suspect, the prosecution will have to prove that the defendant intended to damage someone else's property and demonstrate his actions. If the purpose is to escape during an emergency, even if the belt breaks, there is no malicious intent to damage other people's property, and the person cannot be convicted under criminal law. However, the situation is different with regard to civil law. Civil law establishes lower requirements than criminal law for the concept of “intent,” and in certain circumstances, it may accept the act of damaging another’s property to escape danger as an act to “Avoid an emergency.” Because the law does not explicitly indicate whether passengers can cut their seat belts in these cases, the question arises as to whether passengers have the right to do so to escape and whether they must subsequently compensate the transport company for losses. Furthermore, if the passenger does not compensate the carrier, is the insurance company responsible? Currently, the law does not regulate this issue; To avoid controversy, perhaps future revisions to the law could do so. Without a clear answer in the future, any legislation from the Hong Kong Government will likely be subject to scrutiny. The second incident occurred on January 27th. A passenger in a wheelchair, surnamed Zheng, caught the bus at the Tin Ma Court stop in Wong Tai Sin, Kowloon. Due to mobility problems, he asked the driver for help to fasten his seat belt. During this process, Zheng expressed concern about the way the belt held him, and asked the driver for explanations, which caused a delay in departure. Another passenger named Li, who was in a hurry to get to work, argued with Zheng. When Zheng picked up his cell phone to film the altercation, Li suddenly snatched the device from his hands and repeatedly hit him in the head with the phone. It is believed that this was the first case to involve a person with special needs in a discussion regarding the use of seat belts on a bus and served to draw important lessons. It demonstrates that it is necessary to take special care with people who have special needs when putting on a seat belt. To solve the problem, the driver must first provide help and other passengers will have to be patient. Keeping quiet on public transport can avoid unnecessary conflicts. Ultimately, assisting people with special needs with seat belts and ensuring their safety during travel is an act of care and compassion, similar to providing priority seats. Perhaps the Hong Kong Government could consider including a clause in the legislation to prevent malicious interference from third parties when the driver is helping a passenger to buckle up. This regulation would ensure that people with special needs can access public services, which is certainly consensual. Only by ensuring that those in need receive quick assistance and when possible the bus continues its journey can the problem be resolved. This regulation would benefit everyone. In addition to reviewing the law, transport companies could provide training to drivers related to the mandatory use of seat belts, to learn how to better deal with these situations. They could also place information inside the buses about the provisions made in relation to the transport of people with special needs, ensuring that all passengers were aware. This would also benefit the image of carriers by providing higher quality services, as well as Hong Kong residents and society as a whole. Next week we celebrate Chinese New Year. I wish all my readers a Happy New Year, good health and continued success for Hoje Macau newspaper. We will meet again on February 24th and at that time we will continue our discussion about the use of seat belts on buses. item.title: Calamity
item.description: “I won’t vote even if they arrest me” We went to Portalegre to help some friends who were desperate about the destruction of their homes, like thousands of Portuguese people from North to South. Kristin, Leonardo and last Saturday in Marta, storms that have already caused 15 deaths. Three storms with lots of rain and wind that left Portugal in a state of calamity. Looking closely, it was a rainstorm similar to the many that happen in England and that does not leave thousands of people in despair and without everything they have managed to accumulate throughout a lifetime of work. One difference is that in Portugal government authorities never knew what planning is. Plan what to do in case of a catastrophe, in case of floods, in case of earthquake, in case of a plane crash in Lisbon, in case of purchasing and storing a batch of generators if there is an energy blackout. Planning is a word unknown to those who govern. They worry about day to day life and the announcement of an airport in Alcochete, which should be operational there by the year 2045 and with a TGV from Lisbon to Badajoz. In this last case of the TGV, it would be better if the Government had decided on a TGV between Beja and Lisbon and Beja airport was already operating as Lisbon's international airport. But let's go back to Portalegre and where several Alentejo residents told us, as an act of revolt and despair, similar to Leiria, Marinha Grande, Alcácer do Sal, Ourém, Coimbra or Régua, that “I won't vote even if they arrest me”. In fact, the second round of the presidential elections took place yesterday in most of the national territory, although some municipalities decided to postpone them due to a lack of minimum conditions to open polling stations. The calamity that struck Portugal, some say is unprecedented, has been something horrible. Isolated villages, agricultural fields that disappeared, houses that flew away, hundreds of roofs that disappeared, factories where everything was destroyed and workers were unemployed for many months, thousands of fallen trees, hundreds of cars destroyed, floods of water that invaded houses, hotels and restaurants – some up to the ceiling, displaced homes, exhausted firefighters, a lady cooking in a cubicle for 300 families in a housing unit, marine boats non-stop transporting people who already had a house flooded, animals that were left without stables or kennels, food that did not reach certain populations. There are still thousands of Portuguese people without energy, water and telecommunications. A tragedy that struck a people who never imagined such a catastrophe was possible. However, one very important aspect must be highlighted: solidarity. We remember, for example, the attitude of the people of Trás-os-Montes, particularly in Mirandela, where the Parish Councils got together and acquired tons of tiles that were taken to Marinha Grande in a 16-wheel truck facilitated by the owner. The solidarity between one another has been endless and has been a great display of humanism in the faces of those in government who simply visit the misfortunes experienced by the populations and who tomorrow are already planning their summer holidays in the Algarve or Punta Cana. The first storm Kristin was recorded almost two weeks ago, but state support for those left with nothing may only arrive this week. Insurance companies are starting to “skate” when it comes to putting things in black and white regarding the payment of the losses that each citizen suffered due to the bad weather. Insurance companies should be subject to large fines when they do not comply with stipulations in favor of those affected. They only think about the annual profit… And now? Experts ask about the future, if new Leonardos or Martas continue to appear? The Government must give a quick answer about the future and what it plans to reform so that something changes with positive decisions. And starting with the ‘Civil Protection’ institution, which does not have the humility to admit that its system is full of insufficiencies. It was two weeks of horror, panic, suffering and loss. There were women and men who went more than four days without sleeping an hour. Looking around and just seeing water rising and destroying the refrigerator, the washing machine, the stove, the carpets and all the material values ​​that decorate a house was something very sad. Televisions showed the tears of men and women who were left with absolutely nothing. The country cannot continue like this, because the country is not poor, what exists are too many thieves.

item.title: Bruno Pernadas releases album “unlike,maybe”
item.description: Guitarist and composer Bruno Pernadas, who has performed in Macau and the Greater Bay Area, releases “unlike, maybe” this week, an album with part of the songs created in collaboration with the musicians who accompany him, something he intends to do more of in the future. After “Private Reasons”, released in 2021 and which ends a trilogy, Bruno Pernadas presents “a transition album”. “I'm still not being able to achieve what I wanted, but this is a necessary step for that to happen in the future”, he stated, in an interview with the Lusa agency, regarding “unlike, maybe”, to be published this Friday. The process of creating the album served the musician to try to “detach from certain things that can be considered vices of resources and tools”, something that “is not such an immediate process”, as it is within himself. The recordings were divided between Lisbon, where the musician lives, and Porto. In the ‘invicta city’, the musicians spent a few days in the same house “and this process was collaborative”. "More has already happened [on this album], but I want that to happen, in the future, that's all. There doesn't even need to be demos. Sometimes I don't have demos, I put everything on the agenda", he stated. Other languages The collaborative process allowed Bruno Pernadas to get closer to the language that for him “is closer to jazz, an idea that was left by the trends of Sun Ra, Don Cherry, Alice Coltrane, Art Ensemble of Chicago, The Last Poets – which is not quite jazz, but it is close”. "I wanted to get closer to that language, with which I have a lot of relationship and which didn't happen on other albums. Even on my jazz album 'worst summer ever' [from 2016 and which opened the trilogy] this way of thinking like that wasn't realized. On this album ['unlike, maybe'] it already partially exists", he said. The new album features the participation of musicians Margarida Campelo, António Quintino, João Correia, Diogo Alexandre, José Soares, Teresa Costa, Jéssica Pina and Eduardo Lála. Margarida Campelo also sings, and her voice is joined by those of guests Leonor Arnaut, Lívia Nestrovski and Maya Blandy. Some are already part of the group that accompanied him in previous works, for others it was a debut. "It's like a cast. In cinema there are many directors who have a fixed cast, but sometimes another type of approach to the artistic object is needed and they form collaborations", he said. In addition to playing, Bruno Pernadas is the composer, author and producer of “unlike, maybe”, sharing only one of the lyrics with Rita Westwood. When he goes to the studio with the musicians, “things are more or less thought out”. "There are sections that I leave open for improvisations, thinking about the musicians who are going to record. I already know how people react and there are certain things that are done with that person in mind. There are other melodies and things that I do for the people that I invite to participate in certain songs", he shared. In addition to studio recordings, Bruno Pernadas also incorporates recordings made at home, during the day and without acoustic isolation, into his albums. "I always record things at home. At first I re-recorded, but then I stopped doing that, the sounds aren't bad, it's a clinical, surgical perspective of people listening to the music. It's not bad, that's how it turned out", he said.

item.title: Valentine's Day | Macau Orchestra brings special concert
item.description: This Saturday, the Macau Orchestra will take the stage at the Broadway Theater for a show that celebrates love and, more specifically, Valentine's Day. It is “Symphonic Circus – Film Melodies”, which features Tony Cheng-Te Yeh as conductor and a special performance by the group “Cirque de la Symphonie” The concert entitled “Symphonic Circus – Film Melodies” takes place this Saturday, starring the Macau Orchestra (OM), and taking place at the Broadway Theatre, in Cotai. In order to celebrate Valentine's Day, this show, presented from 8pm, not only features classical music, under the baton of maestro Tony Cheng-Te Yeh, but also features a special performance by “Cirque de la Symphonie”. According to an official note about the concert, this promises to be “a night full of fun in a show that integrates magic, clowning, mime, juggling, dancing, acrobatics and aerial performances with circus props of all shapes and sizes”. Regarding music, OM will perform “popular themes from ballet, opera and even Hollywood, crossing genres and spanning centuries”. According to the organization, “each number of this show promises to delight and inspire, alternating between demonstrations of strength and resistance, and moments of flexibility and lightness”. The concert is described as “one of OM’s most colorful performances this season”, featuring “a parade of wonders”. Melodies in March Meanwhile, another concert starring OM was also announced for March 3rd, but this time in the Ruins of São Paulo. It is “Unforgettable Melodies in the Ruins of São Paulo” which aims to “celebrate the Lantern Festival with the public”. On March 3rd there will be two sessions, one at 6pm and the other at 7pm, both with free entry. According to a note from the Cultural Institute (IC), which promotes the show, the baton will be in the hands of resident conductor Liao Yuan-Yu, presenting “a selection of festive pieces and popular Chinese works to celebrate the Lantern Festival with music aficionados”. The IC explains that each concert will last 30 minutes, and on the day of the show measures will be implemented to control the flow of people within the venue. When maximum capacity is reached, no more people will be allowed to enter. Viewers can also follow the live broadcast of the concerts through various online platforms.

item.title: FRC | Challenges facing Macanese gastronomy today under debate
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) presents today, starting at 6:30 pm, another session of the new cycle of conferences under the theme “Being Macanese in the 21st Century – Culture, Tradition, Identity, Challenges”, with the third round table entitled “Macanese Gastronomy and the Challenges of its Dissemination”. The session will be led by José Luís de Sales Marques, President of the Council of Macanese Communities, bringing together as guest speakers chefs Antonieta Manhão (Neta), professor of Macanese cuisine at the Macau Tourism University; Florita Alves, from La Famiglia Restaurant; Marina Senna Fernandes, from Restaurante Macaísta; and Sónia Palmer, from Cozinha D. Aida, four distinguished local representatives of the traditional culinary arts. Macanese gastronomy is described in a statement about the event as having “originality, transporting its flavors and aromas to the four corners of the world, where the Portuguese traveled”, being the result of “harvesting from the global world and, therefore, deservedly considered the first fusion cuisine in the world”. "It is, for this reason, also a unique landmark of the Macanese identity, and intangible heritage of Macau and the People's Republic of China, making a significant contribution to the classification of Macau, by UNESCO in 2017, as a Creative City of Gastronomy. However, there is still a long distance between recognition and its dissemination, making it accessible to the general public", says the event organizers The session aims to address “the way of life of the Macanese, the community or communities, in Macau and in the diaspora, and their daily challenges to maintain the being and feeling of the Macanese reality”. The purpose of the conference is to promote a “constructive discussion looking at the present and the future, without forgetting the tradition and different identity landmarks, especially Gastronomy and Theater in Patuá, both Intangible Heritage of the Macao SAR and the People's Republic of China”.

item.title: Aren Noronha collected testimonies that refer to the colonial period in Goa
item.description: Aren Noronha is studying for a master's degree in Portuguese and Lusophone Studies at the University of Goa and remembered to collect testimonies from people who had some connection to the language; This Thursday he presents a book containing 45 films, entitled “Lusophone Goa”. When, last year, the 22-year-old, then in the first year of his master's degree, visited the Central Library of Goa, he came across “extremely interesting books from Goa and Macau, all in Portuguese and dating from the colonial period”, which confronted him with “questions about the history of the Portuguese language in Goa today”, he told Lusa. “Like others of my generation, I had only a superficial idea about the situation in Goa and the decline of the language”, acknowledged Aren, when he came across that bibliographic collection, which he could barely read. His parents suggested that he delve deeper into “these questions” and it was they who gave him the idea of ​​collecting “first-person stories, which could become a book, if there were enough answers”, says the master's student, explaining that his father has a small independent publishing house in Panjim, capital of the state of Goa. Good surprise In February 2025, Aren sent “a conceptual note” to “many people who had some connection to the language, asking if they would like to share their testimonies” and received “a surprising number of positive responses”, 45 in total, which he then organized into an equal number of chapters throughout the 294 pages of “Lusophone Goa”, written in English. The testimonies collected are as diverse as the sources are dispersed, both in geographical terms and due to the occupation of each of the voices or the age group of the reporters, uniting them only by the fact that they are Goans or descendants of Goans and have a story to tell about the “relationship with the language”, which in all cases goes far beyond the borders of linguistics. Aren Noronha collected 45 life stories and each one made up a film. The cardiologist and writer based in the United States, Anthony Gomes, and the former curator of the Central Library of Goa, Pia Rodrigues, talk about school and university life in the former Portuguese colony before 1961, as well as the books and magazines that circulated then. Life stories The Goan doctor in Brazil, Carlos Peres da Costa, also remembers his student days, but emphasizes that the manuals he used to complete the course at the then Medical-Surgical School of Goa were written in French, Spanish and English. Writer Ben Antão, based in Canada, faced difficulties learning Portuguese at school, before 1961, because the method was based on memory. Musician Dilip Chico, based in Australia, remembers that the family read the daily “O Heraldo” in Portuguese and wrote letters and postcards in Portuguese to family members in Bombay, corrected by their grandmother. The pretext of each of the stories is language, but they all reveal intimacy, even those with a more scientific content, such as that of Sandra Ataíde Lobo, researcher at the Center for Humanities, at the Faculty of Social and Human Sciences of Universidade Nova de Lisboa, who, based on her grandmother's writings, analyzes the role that Portuguese-language newspapers and periodicals played in Goa as an intellectual space, and the way in which literacy in Portuguese contributed to the development of Konkani writing in characters Romans. “A language is not just words and phrases”, writes Sharmila Pais, History teacher at St Xavier’s College, in Mapuçá, in the state of Goa. “Portuguese makes me me”, seems to respond Omar de Loiola Pereira, a musician from Goa. Aren Noronha is not of Portuguese descent. He has been part of a family of “local converts from Goa” for “eight or ten generations”. "I come from a family that is mostly English-speaking, but multilingual. My parents don't speak Portuguese; my grandparents, however, spoke Brazilian Portuguese, as they lived in Cubatão [a municipality in the state of São Paulo] for a decade", he tells Lusa, or rather, he writes, because he can "think better and respond". Aren also never visited any Portuguese-speaking country. He is thinking about “going to Daman” soon,” he says, but he is “in contact with the Open University and the University of Macau to explore possibilities of doing a PhD in Lusophone Studies” at one of the two institutions, he adds. “If I have the opportunity, I would really like to go to a Lusophone country,” he says.

item.title: Light Rail | Correspondence with buses later this year
item.description: Anyone who takes a public bus after leaving the Light Metro will have a discount on the fare, similar to what happens with buses. The measure will be implemented later this year. Rail transport will also have turnstiles and electronic payments This year, the Directorate of Services for Traffic Affairs (DSAT) will implement fare matching between the Light Metro and public buses, allowing you to pay a discounted ticket for the second transport between the Light Metro and the bus, or vice versa. The measure should start this year, confirmed yesterday the deputy director of DSAT, Mok Soi Tou, to the microphones of Forum Macau, on the Chinese channel of Radio Macau. The issue of correspondence was raised by a listener and the head of DSAT said that the correspondence will be carried out taking advantage of two moments. “We will take advantage of the opportunities to update access machines (turnstiles) to the Light Metro and the renewal of public bus concession contracts, to start correspondence this year”, said Mok Soi Tou. The official added that bus routes will be adjusted as more Light Rail stations are opened, and that bus stops and pedestrian facilities will be improved and provided with information on transport correspondence. Open doors The head of DSAT highlighted that since the creation of the Light Metro, bus routes have always been adapted as new stations open. The opening of the metro station at Portas do Cerco will lead to many changes to the bus routes that serve the busiest point for people in the territory. The deputy director expects that the majority of tourists entering Macau will use the Light Metro to get to Cotai. For his part, the director of the Macau Light Rail Society, Ng Keng Chung, said that the installation of turnstiles is scheduled for the third quarter of this year, allowing payment platforms to be used via QR code, similar to what happens on buses. MPay, Alipay and WeChat Pay applications will be accepted. The replacement of turnstiles will not be done all at once, and Light Metro stations will now have automatic ticket machines that accept electronic payments. DSOP director Lam Wai Hou did not rule out the possibility of the Light Metro network having more than six lines and maintained the forecast that the Eastern Line would be opened in 2029.

item.title: Ruins of S. Paulo | Restoration of bronze statues completed
item.description: The Cultural Institute (IC) announced yesterday that the second phase of the restoration and maintenance work on the bronze statues in the Ruins of St. Paul was successfully completed. As such, the archaeological site behind the façade of the Ruins of St. Paul (including the Museum of Sacred Art and Crypt, and the virtual reality exhibition at the Ruins of St. Paul) have reopened to the public. The restoration and maintenance work on the city's emblematic landmark was divided into three phases. The first phase, completed last year, focused on the statue of the Virgin Mary on the third level and the two bronze statues to the right of the second level. The second phase, which mainly involved the two bronze statues on the left of the second level and the statue of Jesus Christ on the fourth level. The next and final phase will be the restoration this year of the Dove statue, located on the upper level. The restoration team is made up of experts from the Palace Museum, international experts in metal conservation and professionals from higher education institutions in Macau. The IC said that the restoration plan took into account “factors such as typhoon season, workplace safety, peak tourist periods and major events”.

item.title: Zone A | Ten more cameras from the “Eyes in the Sky” system in operation
item.description: The first 10 cameras of the Macau video surveillance system, known as “Eyes in the Sky”, came into operation in Zone A of the New Landfills, in compliance with the order of the Secretary for Security, published yesterday in the Official Bulletin, which comes into force today. According to a statement also released yesterday by the Unitary Police Services (SPU), “in conjunction with the development plan for Zone A of the New Landfills, security authorities plan to install, in phases, 120 cameras in this area”. The first dozen cameras were installed in the peripheral areas of the Tong Seng, Tong Chong and Tong Kai Buildings, covering the main roads and pedestrian crossings, among other public spaces The authorities indicate that, currently, the “Eyes in the Sky” system has 1,711 cameras, and that in the first nine months of 2025, the system supported the investigation of 7,131 crimes, “involving cases of homicide, drug trafficking, robbery, theft, arson, possession of a prohibited weapon, harm to physical integrity, fraud and illegitimate appropriation of found property”. The SPU also added that the expansion of the video surveillance system aims to increase the capacity for security prevention and control, “with a view to preventing and combating criminal activities, providing scientific and technological support for Macau's security”.

item.title: CPSP | Arrested with alcohol content of 1.46 g/l
item.description: A resident was detained by the Public Security Police Corps (CPSP), while driving a motorcycle drunk, in Praça das Portas do Cerco, after trying to cross the border. The case was revealed yesterday by the CPSP, which reported having discovered the illegality because when trying to cross the border the man had a strong odor of alcohol, which did not go unnoticed by the agents. They asked the driver to test the balloon, which gave a result of 1.46 grams of alcohol per liter of blood. When questioned by the agents, the man confessed to having had dinner and drinks with friends in the interior, before trying to return to Macao. The case was forwarded to the Public Prosecutor's Office and the man is charged with the crime of driving under the influence of alcohol. Accident | Driver accused of not giving way A motorcyclist aged around 20 had to be transported to the Centro Hospitalar Conde de São Januário, after colliding with a vehicle that crossed the road. The case happened yesterday morning, on Avenida do Hospital do Cotai. The driver of the motorcycle was thrown after the collision with the light vehicle, ending up lying on the road. Images of the collision were captured by a vehicle traveling on that road and went viral. To the newspaper Ou Mun, the Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) indicated that the driver of the light vehicle is around 80 years old and was fined on suspicion of not giving way at a mandatory stop sign. The CPSP confirmed that the driver in question was not drunk. The CPSP also noted that the motorcyclist was conscious and was able to answer the medical team's questions when he was transported to the hospital. PJ | Man detained on suspicion of illegal exchange On Sunday, a man from Mainland China was detained by Judiciary Police (PJ) agents while making an illegal money exchange. According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the arrest resulted from a PJ inspection of a casino in Cotai. In addition to the arrest, 19 thousand Hong Kong dollars in tokens and a cell phone were seized, which were intended for illegal exchange. Questioned during the investigation, the customer said he exchanged 9,050 renminbi for 10,000 Hong Kong dollar tokens for gambling. The agents also found a 1,000 Hong Kong dollar chip that the witness kept after losing the rest in the game. The suspect confessed that he started the illegal exchange since this month, for every exchange of 10 thousand Hong Kong dollars he could make a profit of 100 Hong Kong dollars. Until his arrest, he had earned 2,000 Hong Kong dollars.

item.title: BNU | Profits shrink by about a quarter by 2025
item.description: The profits of the bank owned by Caixa Geral de Depósitos have been falling for two years, but remain positive. Last year, BNU managed to reduce losses related to non-performing loans Banco Nacional Ultramarino (BNU) in Macau yesterday announced a 26.3 percent drop in net profits in 2025, the second consecutive year in which the financial institution's revenues shrank. According to a statement, the bank recorded unaudited net profits of 431.2 million patacas, 153.9 million patacas less than in 2024. BNU had already recorded a 0.4 percent drop in revenue in 2024. The bank pointed out as the main reason for the drop in profits a reduction of 13.9 percent (138 million patacas) in the net financial margin, the difference between income from loans and interest paid on deposits. BNU indicated that the net financial margin shrank, “driven mainly by the evolution of interest rates”. This is after the Macau Monetary Authority approved three cuts in the main reference interest rate in 2025, the last of which was a cut of 0.25 percentage points, introduced on December 11, following in all cases the North American Federal Reserve. The reduction in net financial margin “was partially offset” by a 2.3 percent increase in commissions charged by the bank, “reflecting greater customer engagement”. Malparado weighed BNU also indicated that it suffered losses of 30 million patacas with non-performing loans and financial investments, 15.3 percent less than in 2024. “This reduction reflects prudent risk management and the stable quality of the bank's assets, supported by conservative credit practices and a robust provisioning margin maintained throughout the year”, guaranteed the institution. “BNU’s capital and liquidity position remains strong, supported by disciplined financial management and a robust risk control system”, indicated the bank. BNU is headquartered in Macau and belongs to the Caixa Geral de Depósitos Group (CGD), being, together with the Bank of China, a currency issuer in Macau. According to official data, Macau banks achieved profits of 7.34 billion patacas in 2025, almost double that recorded in the previous year (92.7 percent more). Non-performing loans fell 11.6 percent over the past year to 49.7 billion patacas. It was the first annual drop in non-performing loans since 2013. Overdue loans represented 4.9 percent of Macau banks' loans, 0.6 percentage points less than at the end of 2024. A percentage that rises to 5.6 percent in the case of credit to institutions or individuals outside the region. The European Banking Authority, the EU regulatory agency, for example, considers that banks with at least 5 percent of non-performing loans have “high exposure” to risk and must establish a strategy to resolve the problem. Even so, the percentage of overdue bank credit in Macau is far from the record of 25.3 percent reached in mid-2001, in the midst of the global economic crisis caused by the bursting of the speculative bubble of companies linked to the Internet.

item.title: Pearl Metropolis | Age kept potential buyers away
item.description: After it was revealed that only 338 of the 1,932 Pearl Horizon victims went ahead to purchase a replacement home in the Pearl Metropolis building, Franky Fong Wai Hong, president of the Macau Real Estate Agents Association, explained that the low rate of buyers was due to several factors and not just the price of new homes. To the newspaper Exmoo, Fong indicated that more than 10 years have passed since the families committed to buying houses in Pearl Horizon and the construction of Pearl Metropolis. Over time, the availability of families to ask for bank loans has changed considerably, because they will have fewer years to pay the requested amount. Furthermore, it was also indicated that the criteria for accessing loans for the purchase of housing have become more stringent. Franky Fong Wai Hong also indicated that people who needed to buy a home 10 years ago were not willing to wait so long for new apartments, which also contributed to the decrease in interest. Even so, if the public capital company Macau Renovação Urbana intends to sell the remaining houses on the market, Franky Fong Wai Hong admitted that current prices are high and that it may be necessary to reduce them to attract buyers.

item.title: Real Estate | Agency expects exemption effects after 1st quarter
item.description: The director of the Sun City real estate group says that so far the market has not yet reflected the tax exemptions launched by the Government, but believes that the effect will begin to be felt after the first quarter of 2026. The person in charge pointed to the sacrifice of profits and reduction of inventory as factors that led to the slight increase in sales The sacrifice of profits and the need to reduce property inventories for new homes may explain part of the tenuous recovery in apartment sales in Macau, explains the director of the Sun City real estate group, Lei Choi Hong. The person responsible points out that these tactics are used to attract buyers and get them to exchange their home for a larger one. Speaking to the newspaper Cheng Pou, the director of the real estate group explained the sector's “survival tactics”, at a time when she says the effects of stamp duty exemptions, among other incentives launched by the Government, have not yet been felt in the market. Despite public measures, Lei Choi Hong does not expect improvements in sales before the end of March. However, since the second half of last year, the person in charge considers that the market has improved slightly, with more customers visiting properties and sales registering a slight increase. The drop in property prices also slowed down, especially after the Government announced measures for the real estate market. The increase in activity in the sector, from the real estate director's perspective, may indicate a tendency for consumer confidence to recover, although there are still many reticences due to fears of instability in the work environment and the ability to pay mortgages. Inversion of the paradigm Regarding the type of apartment, Lei Choi Hong reports the greater interest among buyers in small and medium-sized houses, taking into account the size of households and the financial capacity to pay bank loans. Another factor listed by the person in charge is the tendency, which began to be felt during the pandemic, of Macau residents beginning to prefer renting a house instead of buying it, a reversal that reflects the loss of confidence in the market. Lei Choi Hong hopes that optimizing the visa policy for large investors will attract capital to the region, in order to revitalize the luxury segment of the real estate market, as well as qualified professionals from technology sectors. In this chapter, he suggested that the Government increase the capital criteria for investment projects, for example, requiring candidates to purchase properties with a minimum value of 10 million patacas.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. He says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the measure of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and writers from the north Macua-Mozambican, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the place of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, deferred, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: Nuclear | Moscow says it will continue to comply with the treaty if the US does so
item.description: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said yesterday that Moscow will continue to comply with the limits imposed on its nuclear arsenal, despite the recent end of the New START treaty, as long as the United States does the same. These restrictions “will remain in force, but only as long as the United States does not exceed the limits stipulated” in the treaty, Lavrov said in an intervention made yesterday in the Russian parliament. Moscow “will act in a responsible and considered manner, based on an analysis of US military policy (…) and an analysis of the general strategic situation”, he added. Russia and the United States have by far the largest nuclear arsenals in the world, but since the New START Treaty expired earlier this month, there is no nuclear disarmament agreement linking the two powers. The treaty, signed in 2010 between Russia and the United States, limited the number of nuclear missile launchers to intercontinental distances. It expired on February 5th, as US President Donald Trump did not respond to Moscow's proposal to extend it.

item.title: AI | Bytedance launches new model capable of generating more realistic videos
item.description: Technological advances are multiplying at a breakneck speed. ByteDance's new artificial intelligence model presents itself as a turning point in the film and television sectors Chinese technology company ByteDance has attracted the attention of users and investors after launching an artificial intelligence model for video generation that analysts say “exceeds expectations in terms of realism”. The new application, called Seedance 2.0, was launched this weekend, and its capabilities have already resulted in significant rises in the stock market for companies, not only in the technology sector, but also in the entertainment industry, with some of them reaching the daily earnings limit in recent sessions. According to economic news portal Caixin, this model is capable of generating realistic images with fluid movements, also adding sounds that coincide with the images, which for the first time puts ByteDance in a position to compete with KlingAI, developed by the short video platform Kuaishou. Feng Ji, producer of the popular video game Black Myth: Wukong, described Seedance 2.0 as “the most powerful video generation model yet,” and predicted a major impact on reducing production costs for film and television, as well as other types of content. The official Seedance 2.0 portal states that the big difference compared to similar models is its ability to maintain the coherence of the characters in different scenes. New chapter According to analysts at Kaiyuan Securities, cited by the Bloomberg agency, this new model could mark a turning point in the use of AI in film and television: "The test results are impressive. It supports text, image, video and audio input, and has achieved significant progress in crucial capabilities." Feng also warned of the risks of the proliferation of fake videos generated by these types of services, which could lead to a crisis of trust: “Realistic fake videos will be available to everyone, and intellectual property and supervision systems will face unprecedented challenges.” "In the future, any video content that does not have an official and authorized backing – especially those with personal images and voices – may be fake. Please be sure to verify them through multiple channels to avoid being scammed," the producer wrote on social media. Seedance 2.0 did not reach the market in isolation, as its great local rival, the aforementioned KlingAI, launched its 3.0 version on the 4th, with intelligent framing and the ability to add new images and people to the original video as major attractions.

item.title: CNOOC starts searching for hydrocarbons in Mozambique in March
item.description: The Mozambican Energy Minister, Estêvão Pale, assured that the Chinese state oil company CNOOC will begin exploring for hydrocarbons in March with the drilling of up to six blocks of the concession awarded in the sixth tender, launched in 2021. "They will start very soon. In March, they will start preparing to start exploration", said the Minister of Mineral Resources and Energy, Estêvão Pale, questioned by journalists at the Mining Indaba conference, which has been taking place since Monday in Cape Town, South Africa. “Right now, we are in the initial phase, five to six more blocks”, he also replied, regarding the drilling holes to be carried out by the Chinese National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) in deep waters of the Rovuma Basin, north of the country. The previous Mozambican Government approved on March 26, 2024 five terms of concession contracts for the production of hydrocarbons – essentially natural gas – in the country, the then spokesperson for the Council of Ministers announced at that time. “As part of the implementation of the mineral resources policy (…), the Government of Mozambique continued with actions aimed at seeking more investments for the oil sector”, said the Government spokesperson at that time. In December 2022, the National Petroleum Institute announced the award of these blocks to CNOOC, as a result of the sixth tender for gas and oil prospecting, launched on November 25, 2021. On the ground The current Minister of Energy, Estêvão Pale, questioned at the same event, assured that, for now, Mozambique has no plans for a new round of auctions for oil and gas blocks. "Not now, because we think that there are still many areas for direct negotiations, which were part of the last round, that have not been developed. We now have the opportunity to continue discussions and see if we can find another potential partner", he said. Mozambique has three development projects approved to explore natural gas reserves in the Rovuma basin, classified among the largest in the world, off the coast of Cabo Delgado. Eni's Coral Sul project is the only one in operation since 2022, and investment in a second floating platform for extraction, called Coral Norte, was approved last October, in an investment of 7.2 billion dollars, which from 2028 will allow production to be doubled to 7 million tons per year (mtpa) of liquefied natural gas. After four years of suspension due to the terrorist attacks in Cabo Delgado, the $20 billion Mozambique LNG project (Area 1), operated by TotalEnergies, officially resumed last January and is expected to produce up to 13 mtpa from 2029, followed by the $30 billion Rovuma LNG project (Area 4), operated by ExxonMobil, with 18 mtpa expected after 2030, and whose final investment decision is expected this year.

item.title: Economy | Inflation eases as food prices fall
item.description: Inflation in China slowed down in January, after reaching the highest value in the last three years in December, mainly influenced by the fall in food prices, according to official data released yesterday. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.2 percent year-on-year in January, a slowdown from the 0.8 percent recorded in December, according to China's National Bureau of Statistics. Food prices fell 0.7 percent in January, reversing the 1.1 percent rise recorded in the previous month. The prices of non-food products rose 0.4 percent, less than the 0.8 percent in December. The underlying CPI, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, rose 0.8 percent year on year, after rising 1.2 percent in December. In monthly terms, the IPC registered a positive variation of 0.2 percent in January, the same value as in December. The data contradicts the deflationary cycle that has hit China for around two years. The Production Price Index (IPP) fell 1.4 percent in January compared to the same month last year, an improvement compared to the 1.9 percent drop in December, but remaining in deflationary territory for the 40th consecutive month.

item.title: Space | New rocket and spacecraft tests completed in the plan to take astronauts to the Moon
item.description: China flight-tested the Mengzhou spacecraft's escape system and the first stage of the Long March-10 rocket, advancing preparations to send astronauts to the Moon before 2030. The test took place yesterday at the Wenchang space center in the southern island province of Hainan, state television CCTV reported, citing China's Manned Space Program Office. The test included a low-altitude demonstration of the Long March-10 system and an escape test under conditions of maximum dynamic pressure for the Mengzhou spacecraft. At 11:00, the rocket took off until it reached the point scheduled for activating the evacuation system. The ship then received the escape signal and successfully separated from the launcher. Both the rocket's first stage and the return capsule landed in a controlled manner in the designated maritime zone. According to the authorities, this is the first flight activation of the Long March-10 in initial prototype status, the first Chinese escape test under conditions of maximum dynamic pressure and the first recovery at sea of ​​both the first stage of a launcher and a manned capsule within the scope of this program. The test continues the tests carried out last year on the aforementioned Mengzhou spacecraft and the Lanyue landing module. These developments are part of the technical scheme envisaged for a manned lunar mission, which China plans to carry out before 2030, in parallel with the preparation of a research station at the lunar south pole and the continued development of its own space station, Tiangong.

item.title: Seoul | Authorities investigate case of drones sent to the North
item.description: South Korean authorities yesterday declared that they had searched the country's civil and military secret services as part of an investigation into the theft of a drone that crossed the border with the North in January. North Korea accused the South of having sent a drone to its territory in early January and claimed to have shot down the device near the city of Kaesong, not far from the inter-Korean border. KCNA, North Korea's official agency, established a link with another South Korean drone flight carried out, according to Pyongyang, near the border city of Paju, in September. Seoul has denied any government or army involvement, suggesting that civilians could be responsible, but yesterday South Korean authorities announced that they are investigating three soldiers and an intelligence official suspected of involvement. Search and seizure warrants were executed “at 18 locations in total, including the Defense Intelligence Command and the National Intelligence Service,” according to a statement. Three civilians have been charged for their alleged role in the drone scandal. One of them publicly claimed responsibility, claiming to have piloted the device to measure levels of radiation and heavy metal contamination around a uranium processing plant in the North. South Korean President Lee Jae-myung denounced this overflight, warning that it was an initiative that could trigger a war. His deposed predecessor, Yoon Suk-yeol, is currently on trial for illegally ordering drone overflights over North Korea, hoping to provoke a reaction from Pyongyang and use it as a pretext for a failed attempt to impose martial law. Yoon Suk-yeol was removed last April for this attempt.

item.title: Japan | Takaichi's Party Secures Two-Thirds of Parliament
item.description: Sanae Takaichi's ultraconservative party won a categorical victory in Sunday's elections, crushing Japanese centrist and leftist representations. Friend Donald has already sent congratulations Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's Liberal Democratic Party (PLD) won 315 seats in Sunday's early legislative elections, alone obtaining a two-thirds majority in the Lower House of Parliament, according to official results published yesterday. This result is the best in the history of the PLD and allows the ultra-conservative leader to consolidate her mandate to implement the expansive economic program in the archipelago of 123 million inhabitants over the next four years. Becoming the first woman to lead the Japanese Government in October and enjoying a state of grace since then, Takaichi dissolved the Lower House of Parliament at the end of January, where her government coalition had the majority. Bet largely won: the coalition formed by the PLD and Ishin (Party for Innovation, center-right) obtained a total of 351 seats out of the 465 that make up the Lower Chamber, according to data from the Ministry of the Interior. In the previous legislature, the PLD had just 198 seats, while Ishin held 34. The elections also saw the anti-immigration party Sanseito increase its number of seats, from two to fifteen, according to the results. The new Centrist Alliance for Reform, formed by the main opposition party, the Constitutional Democratic Party (center-left), and the PLD's former partner, the small Buddhist party Komeito, suffered a crushing defeat, with the number of seats falling from 167 to 49. Takaichi was warmly congratulated by US President Donald Trump, with whom she is scheduled to meet in mid-March in Washington. Regional disorder The victory places her in the wake of her mentor, Shinzo Abe (prime minister in 2006-2007 and then in 2012-2020), who profoundly marked the country with nationalist positions and an economic program, which included, in particular, budgetary recovery measures. From an external point of view, the Asia-Pacific region will be attentive to the development of Sino-Japanese tensions, which have taken on a new dimension since Sanae Takaichi suggested, in November, that Tokyo could intervene militarily in the event of a Chinese attack on Taiwan, whose sovereignty is claimed by Beijing. Financial markets may also be concerned about the imbalance in Japanese public finances and, above all, the escalation of the already huge public debt, if Takaichi continues to reinforce fiscal stimulus measures to boost the world's fourth largest economy. Strengthened by the prospect of greater budget spending and tax benefits, the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose more than 5 percent in Monday's session and opened again yesterday at gains and new record levels.

item.title: Cars | China overtakes Argentina as the largest exporter of vehicles to Brazil
item.description: Chinese manufacturers consolidate their presence in the largest automotive market in South America, leaving Argentina behind China overtook Argentina in January to become the largest exporter of automobiles to Brazil, consolidating the dominance of Chinese brands in South America's largest automobile market, according to data released by industry sources. According to the specialized platform Autoweb, China exported 16,800 vehicles to Brazil in January, compared to 13,400 units from Argentina. This is a historic reversal in the automobile balance between the two main Mercosur partners, which has been underway since the first quarter of 2024. Unlike Argentine cars, which generally include a high percentage of parts produced in Brazil, Chinese cars arrive fully assembled, bypassing the local supply chain. In value, car imports from China to Brazil reached 375 million dollars (around 315 million euros) in January – more than ten times the value recorded in the same month of the previous year – and represented around 65 percent of the sector's total imports. This pattern follows the global strategy of Chinese brands, which begin their presence through exports and, subsequently, invest in local assembly and production units. In Brazil, manufacturers Great Wall Motors and BYD have led this process. BYD invested 5.5 billion reais (around 890 million euros) in the conversion of the former Ford factory in Camaçari, in the state of Bahia, where it intends to produce vehicles based on the “semi-knocked down” model – in which cars arrive almost ready from China and are finished locally, mostly with imported parts. Criticism and praise The practice has generated criticism from the national association of vehicle manufacturers (Anfavea), which warns of the lower generation of employment in local value chains compared to the traditional model of complete production. O presidente da Anfavea, Igor Calvet, elogiou recentemente a decisão do Governo brasileiro de não renovar a isenção fiscal para a importação de ‘kits’ desmontados, medida que expirou em Janeiro e visa incentivar uma produção nacional mais sofisticada. According to data from Anfavea, Brazilian automobile production fell 12 percent in January compared to the same month in 2025, while sales recorded a slight decline. The market share of electrified vehicles reached an all-time high of 16.8 percent, although only around 35 percent of these were produced in Brazil. Exports fell 18 percent, mainly affected by lower Argentine demand. Despite the strong expansion of Chinese brands in the Brazilian market, Brazil occupies only fifth place among the main destinations for Chinese automobile exports, behind Mexico, Russia, the United Kingdom and the United Arab Emirates. According to the Chinese Passenger Car Association, China exported 8.32 million vehicles in 2025, an increase of 30 percent compared to the previous year, confirming the sector's global growth trend.

item.title: Former defense industry leader accused of corruption
item.description: Beijing yesterday announced corruption charges against Zhang Jianhua, a former defense industry leader, and an investigation into Yi Lianhong, a senior official at the legislative body, in the latest development of the anti-corruption campaign launched by Chinese President Xi Jinping. According to state television CCTV, China's Public Prosecutor's Office filed charges against Zhang Jianhua, former deputy director at the State Administration of Science, Technology and Industry for National Defense, for bribery, alleging that the former official had used the positions he held in the body responsible for the defense industry to benefit third parties in exchange for undue advantages. According to the same source, Zhang abused his position in areas such as project evaluation, finance and auditing to receive “assets of especially high value”. After abandoning public functions, he continued to exploit the influence of the positions previously held to obtain benefits through other employees. Eyes on Defense This process comes at a time of greater scrutiny on the defense sector in China, the target of several investigations into senior military officials in recent months, although the authorities have not established any link between these investigations and Zhang's case. In a separate announcement, the Chinese Communist Party's (CCP) Central Disciplinary Commission and the National Supervision Commission – the country's main anti-corruption bodies – said that Yi Lianhong, vice chairman of the Economic and Finance Commission of the National People's Congress, is being investigated for “serious violations of discipline and law”. The official note, released yesterday on the party committee's website, does not specify the nature of the infractions, which is usual in the initial stages of this type of investigation. Both cases are part of the vast anti-corruption campaign, against “tigers” and “flies” launched by Xi Jinping since he took power in 2012, and which has already affected leaders at all levels – from local officials to provincial leaders, military leaders and those responsible for large public companies – tigers – to low-status employees, flies.

item.title: Marcelo Loureiro, author and teacher: “The indigenato was a continuation of slavery”
item.description: He was recently in Macau to present the book “Colonial Citizenship: law, race and rights through the Portuguese empire”. Marcelo Loureiro's work explores the way in which, in the Portuguese empire, Portuguese citizenship was shaped according to skin color. Macau was no exception, although with different contours compared to Africa, argues the professor at the University of Leicester Image: Rui Cunha Foundation How did this investigation begin and how did the themes of colonialism and citizenship emerge? Tudo nasceu de uma experiência pessoal e familiar. Cresci no Rio de Janeiro, numa família marcada pela diáspora portuguesa por um lado, e pelo silêncio colonial do outro. A minha avó paterna, portuguesa, guardava no fundo de um armário os documentos que me permitiram, aos treze anos, reclamar a cidadania portuguesa. A minha outra avó, mestiça, cafuza, não tinha papéis, não tinha histórias para contar; de ela para mim, existia apenas um silêncio. Esta divisão, entre quem tem direito a documentos e a voz e quem é forçado ao apagamento, foi o ponto de partida para questionar a construção legal da cidadania e da nacionalidade. Quando cheguei a Portugal para estudar Direito em Coimbra, comecei a perceber que a lei que me reconhecia como português era a mesma que historicamente negou esse reconhecimento a milhões de pessoas com base na raça, na ‘civilização’ e na cor da pele. O livro é, em parte, uma tentativa de compreender essa estrutura jurídica de inclusão e exclusão, é uma denúncia da injustiça por detrás dos direitos. É uma denúncia da cidadania como método de exclusão. In the context of the Portuguese empire, when did the first notions of citizenship emerge and what criteria were used? The first formal notions of national belonging in Portugal appear in the Philippine Ordinances of 1603, which establish who should be considered 'natural' of the kingdom. It is interesting to note that the inclusion of the notion of nationality was only included in Portuguese law during the Iberian Union, during the Philippine dynasty, when Spain controlled Portugal through the Habsburgs. It was in this context that Spanish law was transposed to Portugal to separate Portuguese from Spanish. However, the practical construction of Portuguese citizenship begins much earlier, in opposition: through slavery. Since the 15th century, with papal bulls (such as Dum Diversas of 1452 and Romanus Pontifex of 1454), Portugal obtained canonical legitimacy to enslave Africans and conquer their territories. Portuguese citizenship was thus constructed, in opposition to the figure of the ‘other’ – the Moor, the black, the pagan, the ‘savage’, and finally, the ‘indigenous’. What were the differentiation criteria? The criteria were essentially civilizational and racial: being Christian and, progressively, being white or recognized as ‘civilized’ according to European standards. Conversion to Christianity functioned, at times, as a kind of 'spiritual whitening', but even converts rarely achieved full legal equality, which continued to be imposed for centuries. The law called indigenous to all those who existed outside the standard of civilization expected of citizens, which were the non-white populations of Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor.
